intro: Ocimum helianthemifolium, commonly known as the sunflower basil, is a member of the Lamiaceae family and is native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its small, bright yellow flowers and aromatic, slightly hairy leaves that emit a strong basil scent. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and prefers full sun to partial shade. Its foliage is often used in culinary applications, though it is less common than other basil varieties. The plant's botanical features make it a unique and valuable addition to both gardens and herbal collections.
